Comment: virtually none. VP pick has an extremely negligible impact on driving voters in their state, maybe 1% at most.  https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/04/election-2016-vice-president-selection-matters-less-than-you-think-213805/  https://www.npr.org/2024/07/25/nx-s1-5049718/vice-presidential-picks-how-much-do-they-matter  https://ecommons.udayton.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1082&context=pol_fac_pub  https://www.cbsnews.com/minnesota/news/does-the-vice-presidential-pick-matter-to-the-election/  https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-overrated-vice-presidential-home-state-effect/  I dont know where your conclusion of walz being "not the guy" comes from but it doesnt match with the majority consensus opinion. He's been well received and if anything, the campaign spent a period of time under-utilizing him.  Israel and Gaza and Palestine voters who wont vote for Kamala are either betraying their stated cause in favor of helping perpetuate the genocide under trump, and likely represent an EXTREMELY small fraction of voters. The majority of voters barely know anything about what is happening, let alone have a solidified formed opinion on the complicated historical situation etc. Voters are much more likely and more viscerally to care about what will actually affect their material conditions of living on a daily basis in the US. What happens in Gaza realistically will never affect them in any clearly identifiable way.

Author: [deleted]

Comment: This is literally an election where 1 percent will make or break Trump and Harris.  "friendly" reactions to the results of VP debate.  Walz........made JD Vance look good......which should never happen, and that is not a good thing.  And yes, it is important.  In traditional elections, consolidating a state with a VP candidate that can bolster a "critical node" state is extremely important, and has proven to be extremely important historically.  VP has never.......ever been a "national" pick.  It has historically been to pick up one crucial state that you are not sure is "in the bag".  Anyone who thinks Pennsylvania is "in the bag" right now is straight up high.  Israel/Gaza voters COULD decide the election (frankly, so could Ukraine voters in Pennsylvania, but I digress).  It matters.  I could give just as many linked articles indicating the importance of Israel/Palestinian "one issue" voters without 2 minutes of my time......  And this is the sort of "blindsightedness" that loses elections 2016 style.  This is teasing a repeat, make no mistake.  I agree that voters dont know anything, and generally are not overly informed, and thats what makes this even MORE important, because they vote for what they know.........and in Pennsylvania........what they know and that familiarity could have proven to be crucial.  Finally, the last link has validated that "the gain in vice presidential candidate has been more important  in recent years (four points in recent years as opposed to two)".  With THAT margin of error, yeah, that will comfortably make a difference.  Third link provided hardly any substance at all.
